awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Economics: Leveraging Standardized Tests to Measure Noncognitive Skills and Their Effect on College and Labor-Market Outcomes
awd_abstract_narration:
Skills other than intelligence and technical skills, sometimes known as “noncognitive skills,” such as industriousness, perseverance, and self-control, are important labor market outcomes and earnings determinants. Yet, understanding why noncognitive skills influence labor-market outcomes is limited.  Moreover, it is difficult to measure these skills. This research project will use an innovative methodology to measure noncognitive skills and study  the channels through which these skills affect earnings and other labor market outcomes. Using administrative data, the researchers will measure noncognitive skills in high-school students and track them over time to assess how their noncognitive skills relate to their college outcomes and early adulthood labor market outcomes. The project will provide a better understanding of the linkages between noncognitive skills and earnings. The results will provide insight for formulating policies aimed at increasing productivity and economic success in the U.S.  The results of this research will lead to better matching and improved labor market performance, and thus increase economic growth and improve the wellbeing of American citizens.  

There is increasing recognition among social scientists and policymakers that noncognitive skills are important predictors of earnings. However, the channels that mediate the relationship between these skills and labor-market success are not well understood. This project will provide a better understanding of the channels through which noncognitive skills influence labor-market outcomes. This research will create a revealed-preference measure of noncognitive skill based on performance decline of high-school students in a college admission exams. The PIs will link the students’ measured noncognitive skills to a census of all college enrollees and an employee-employer matched dataset. Using these data, the researchers will study the predictive power of noncognitive skills for important outcomes, including college graduation, college quality, field of study, occupation, and firm characteristics. The research will assess how each of these outcomes mediates the link between the measured noncognitive skill and earnings. The results of this project will produce valuable knowledge that may contribute to the design of policies that increase skills in the U.S. workforce and thereby promote productivity and economic growth. The results could lead to better matching and improved labor market performance, and thus increase economic growth and improve the wellbeing of American citizens.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Introduction

There is increasing recognition among social scientists and policymakers that skills other than intelligence, often referred to as noncognitive skills, such as industriousness, perseverance, and self-control, are important predictors of individual-level economic outcomes. This report presents the outcomes of a research study examining the importance of one specific skill known as cognitive endurance, defined as the capacity to sustain performance on a cognitively-demanding task over time. The project studies the role of this skill for success in college and in the labor market. By doing so, the project contributes to our understanding of the economic impacts of noncognitive skills.

 

Intellectual Merit and Project Overview

The main goal of this project was to provide a characterization of the channels through which noncognitive skills can influence labor-market outcomes. The research project specifically focused on the role of cognitive endurance and its influence on performance in standardized tests, college performance, and career outcomes.

The research project leverages administrative records from millions of Brazilian high school students taking a high-stakes college admission exam. The project followed the academic and labor market trajectories of these students to see how cognitive endurance, as measured by the change in performance over the course of the exam, shaped their outcomes. The project utilized multivariate regression analysis to estimate the predicted impacts of cognitive endurance on academic and job outcomes.

 

Key Findings

1. College and career outcomes. The research project found that high-school students with more cognitive endurance are more likely to attend college, enroll in higher-quality colleges, are more likely to graduate, earn higher wages, and work for higher-paying firms. The magnitudes of these associations are sizable. For example, holding other factors constant, a one standard deviation increase in cognitive endurance predicts a 5.4% increase in early-career wages.

2. Earnings returns across occupations. The project also found substantial heterogeneity in the wage return to endurance across occupations. On average, occupations that pay higher wages also offer a higher wage return to endurance, uncovering a novel type of assortative matching between high-endurance workers and high-paying jobs. This finding is relevant given that the sorting between workers and firms is an important driver of labor-market inequality. Furthermore, occupations with a high wage return to endurance also tend to have a high wage return to ability, suggesting these two skills are complements in production.

3. Mechanism behind endurance. The occupational-level results also shed light on the psychological mechanisms behind cognitive endurance. Specifically, some of the occupations with the highest wage return to endurance include those where lapses in sustained attention can have high production costs, like professionals in the aviation industry or facility operators in chemical plants. This suggests that the capacity to sustain focus on a task for a long time may be a psychological mechanism contributing to the wage return to cognitive endurance.

Broader Impacts

The findings of the research have implications for educational equity, the formulation of effective human capital policies, and the design of talent-selection mechanisms.

1. Educational Equity and Test Score Gaps. The project revealed that test-score gaps across socioeconomic statuses could be partly attributed to differences in cognitive endurance. This insight prompts a reevaluation of standardized testing practices, potentially leading to fairer assessment methods.

2. Formulating Effective Human-Capital Policies. The findings of the project suggest that including endurance-building components in education and training could yield significant benefits. This has implications for educational curricula and occupational training programs.

3. Designing More Informative Talent-Selection Mechanisms: The research demonstrated that adjusting exam designs to reduce the emphasis on mental fatigue can significantly increase the predictive validity of test scores for long-term outcomes.

 

Conclusion

Cognitive effort underlies most, if not all, productive activities. The project provides valuable insights into how cognitive endurance influences academic and career trajectories. By documenting the different channels through which cognitive endurance impacts test scores, college, and labor-market outcomes, the project sheds light on how to design more effective mechanisms to identify and train human capital. These findings have the potential to influence policy-making, educational reform, and organizational practices, underscoring the importance of studying noncognitive skills for the design of policies that foster economic productivity.
